title: Structural Studies of Helicobacter pylori’s Cag Type IV Secretion System
content: Helicobacter pylori is a gram-negative bacterium that chronically infects ∼50% of the world’s population [1]. H. pylori colonization in the stomach can lead to gastric inflammation (gastritis) and an increased risk for gastric cancer, peptic ulcer disease, and mucosa-associated lymphoid tissue lymphoma. Gastric cancer is the third leading cause of cancer-related death worldwide, and H. pylori is classified as a type I carcinogen by the World Health Organization [2, 3]. H. pylori strains that harbor the cag pathogenicity island, a 40-kb chromosomal region that encodes a Type IV Secretion System (T4SS) and the secreted effector protein CagA, are more frequently associated with severe disease. CagA is the only protein known to be translocated by the Cag T4SS and once inside cells causes numerous alterations in cell signaling, linking it to malignant transformation. How the T4SS physically translocates CagA is not understood.
